claim: The human body has only one kidney

supporting.text: The human body typically has two kidneys, located on either side of the spine below the rib cage.

attacks.text: The human body typically has two kidneys, located on either side of the spine below the rib cage.
Some individuals are born with only one kidney, a condition known as unilateral renal agenesis.
Unilateral renal agenesis is rare, occurring in approximately 1 in 1,000 to 2,000 live births.
Kidney donations involve surgical removal of one kidney, leaving the donor with only one functioning kidney.
Kidney donors undergo rigorous health screenings to ensure they can live safely with one kidney.

supporting.text: Medical textbooks and anatomical studies consistently describe the human renal system as including two kidneys.

attacks.text: Medical textbooks and anatomical studies consistently describe the human renal system as including two kidneys.
Some individuals are born with only one kidney due to congenital conditions like renal agenesis.
Congenital single-kidney conditions are rare, affecting less than 1 in 1,000 people, making the two-kidney description accurate for the vast majority.
Kidney donations or surgical removal can leave a person with only one functional kidney.
Even post-donation or surgery, the default anatomical structure remains two kidneys, and medical education focuses on this norm.

supporting.text: Kidney transplants involve donors giving one kidney while retaining the other, indicating the presence of two kidneys in a healthy human body.

attacks.text: Kidney transplants involve donors giving one kidney while retaining the other, indicating the presence of two kidneys in a healthy human body.
Some individuals are born with only one kidney due to congenital conditions like unilateral renal agenesis.
Congenital single-kidney conditions are rare, affecting less than 1 in 1,000 people, making the two-kidney structure the biological norm.
Surgical removal of a kidney (nephrectomy) can leave a person with only one functional kidney.
Nephrectomy is a medical exception, not the default anatomical state, and does not contradict the typical two-kidney structure.

supporting.text: Bilateral symmetry in human anatomy includes paired organs such as kidneys, lungs, and eyes.

attacks.text: Bilateral symmetry in human anatomy includes paired organs such as kidneys, lungs, and eyes.
Some individuals are born with a single kidney due to congenital conditions like unilateral renal agenesis.
Congenital single kidney is rare, affecting only about 1 in 1,000 people, making bilateral symmetry the norm.
Kidney donation or surgical removal can result in a person having only one functional kidney.
Surgical or donated single kidneys are exceptions, not the default anatomical structure.

supporting.text: Ultrasound and imaging techniques routinely visualize two kidneys in standard human anatomy.

attacks.text: Ultrasound and imaging techniques routinely visualize two kidneys in standard human anatomy.
Some individuals are born with a single kidney due to congenital conditions like renal agenesis.
Congenital single kidney is rare, affecting only about 1 in 1,000 people, making two kidneys the overwhelming norm.
Medical imaging can sometimes miss a kidney due to technical limitations or atypical positioning.
Modern high-resolution ultrasound and CT scans have >99% accuracy in kidney detection when properly administered.
